title: 49ers' Torrey Smith, Anquan Boldin haunt the Ravens, their former team
text:
49ers' Torrey Smith, Anquan Boldin haunt the Ravens, their former team By Jerry McDonald Posted: 10/18/2015 07:13:36 PM PDT Updated: 10/18/2015 07:18:56 PM PDT 49ers news on Facebook SANTA CLARA -- Torrey Smith delivered the first blow, with teammate and fellow ex-Raven Anquan Boldin helping to finish things off Sunday as the 49ers beat the Baltimore Ravens 25-20 at Levi's Stadium. 
Smith, who signed a five-year, $40 million contract with the 49ers in the offseason, scored on a 74-yard go-route from Colin Kaepernick on precisely the kind of play he was signed to provide. 
The score broke up what had been a field goal battle between the 49ers Phil Dawson and the Ravens' Justin Tucker and put the 49ers up 13-3. 
Boldin, a star on the Ravens' Super Bowl championship team against the 49ers following the 2012 season, caught a 51-yard pass on second-and-11 from Kaepernick after the Ravens were within 19-13. The play helped set up a 21-yard Kaepernick touchdown to Quinton Patton and a 25-13 lead. San Francisco 49ers' Anquan Boldin (81) breaks a tackle after a catch against Baltimore Ravens' Will Hill III (33) in the third quarter of their NFL game at Levi's Stadium in Santa Clara, Calif., on Sunday, Oct. 18, 2015. (Nhat V. Meyer/Bay Area News Group) ( Nhat V. Meyer ) 
Smith downplayed facing his former team all week, and felt pretty much the same way after catching three passes for 96 yards. 
``I said it wasn't a big deal. I still feel that way, even after the game is over,'' Smith said. ``It was weird to look across and know I was competing against them. But I'm all in out West. That doesn't change how special my time was there or how much people in that organization mean to me, but I have a job to do out here.'' 
Smith, averaging 23.1 yards per catch on 14 receptions this season, beat former 49ers Shareece Wright on fake and was led perfectly by Kaepernick for the 74-yard touchdown. 
``That was a double move. I was able to beat him,'' Smith said. ``I had to keep my feet. Kap threw it, I was able to catch it and then I was in the end zone.'' Advertisement 
Boldin finished with five receptions for 102 yards, his second straight game with more than 100, his fifth time with the 49ers and 38th time in his career. 
While Smith left Wright in the dust, Ravens cornerback Jimmy Smith was glued to Boldin on the 51-yard play in the fourth quarter. 
It happened after Kaepernick scrambled to his left, then throwing off-balance and to his wrong side, launched a perfect pass that Boldin caught as he tumbled to the ground. Boldin fell on the ball, knocked the wind out of himself and didn't return, but the damage had been done. 
``Definitely I feel the team looks to me as one of the guys that needs to make a play, to step up,'' Boldin said. ``I always feel that way.'' 
Smith has seen Boldin's act both with Baltimore and the 49ers, so the end result came as no surprise. 
``Any time the ball's up and Anquan' has a chance on it, you've got to believe he's going to come down with it,'' Smith said. ``That was a tough play. Jimmy was all over him. If he doesn't make that play, we probably don't move down the field. We were kind of stalling a little bit.'' 
Kaepernick credited Boldin's ``very strong hands and competitive nature. You put the ball up 99 times out of a hundred, he's going to come down with it.'' San Francisco 49ers wide receiver Torrey Smith (82) hauls in a 76-yard touchdown pass in front of Baltimore Ravens cornerback Shareece Wright (35) in the second quarter of their NFL game at Levi's Stadium in Santa Clara, Calif., on Sunday, Oct. 18, 2015. (D. Ross Cameron/Bay Area News Group) ( D. ROSS CAMERON ) 
Fullback Bruce Miller, who got into the big play act with three receptions for 89 yards in the first quarter, believes Boldin saves his best for the biggest moments. 
``He's made 'em since he showed up here, with contested catches at big points in the game where we need a play and he makes it,'' Miller said. ``You can't put a price on what he does for our offense and our team.'' Follow Jerry McDonald on Twitter at twitter.com/Jerrymcd .
